'''Billy Flynn''' (born August 11, 1956)<ref name="Hanson">{{cite book
| first= Karen
| last= Hanson
| year= 2007
| title= Today's Chicago Blues
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Lake Claremont Press
| location= Chicago
| page= 155
| isbn= 978-1-893121-19-5}}</ref> is an [[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] and [[electric blues]] guitarist, singer and songwriter. 

In addition to his own work, and those mentioned later, Flynn has worked and recorded with [[Bryan Lee]], [[Little Smokey Smothers]], [[Mark Hummel]], [[Willie Kent]], [[Snooky Pryor]], [[Big Bill Morganfield]], [[John Brim]], [[Jody Williams (blues musician)|Jody Williams]], [[Little Arthur Duncan]], [[Deitra Farr]], and [[Billy Boy Arnold]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://billyflynn.com/discography.html |title=Billy Flynn Blues – Discography |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Billyflynn.com |accessdate=December 14, 2011}}</ref>

==Biography==
Flynn was born in [[Green Bay, Wisconsin]], [[United States]].<ref name="Hanson"/><ref name="Blues">{{cite web |url=http://www.bluesinternationalltd.com/tickets-a-info/21 |title=Friday Performers – Kim Wilson's Blues All-Stars featuring Billy Flynn and Kid Ramos |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Bluesinternationalltd.com |accessdate=December 14, 2011}}</ref> In 1970, a local blues [[nightclub|club]] opened and Flynn was inspired by the music provided there by [[Luther Allison]], [[Johnny Littlejohn]] and [[Mighty Joe Young (musician)|Mighty Joe Young]].  Flynn was fortunate to be spotted playing outside the venue by [[Jimmy Dawkins]], who arranged for Flynn to play with him on stage.<ref name="Flynn">{{cite web |url=http://billyflynn.com/biography.html |title=Biography |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Billyflynn.com |accessdate=December 14, 2011}}</ref>  This led to Flynn joining Dawkins' backing band in 1975, and he played and toured with them until the end of the decade.

Flynn also worked locally during this period and played alongside [[Sunnyland Slim]]. In the early part of the 1980s, Flynn was a member of the touring ensemble, Jim Liban and the Futuramics.<ref name="Flynn"/> In the late 1980s, Flynn joined [[The Legendary Blues Band]].  He also had a spell playing with [[Mississippi Heat]].<ref name="Hanson"/>

[[Willie "Big Eyes" Smith]]'s 2008 album, ''Born in Arkansas'', utilized Flynn, plus bassman [[Bob Stroger]], pianist [[Barrelhouse Chuck]], Little Frank Krakowski and his Smith's own son and drummer, Kenny "Beedy Eyes" Smith.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.blues.co.nz/features/article.php?id=288 |title=Born in Arkansas – Willie "Big Eyes" Smith |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Blues.co.nz |accessdate=December 14, 2011}}</ref>

In August 2010, Flynn and [[Kid Ramos]] backed [[Kim Wilson]] at the [[Edmonton's Labatt Blues Festival]].<ref name="Blues"/>
